The MAC Resolvability Region, Semantic Security and Its Operational Implications

Matthias Frey, Igor Bjelakoviƒá and S≈Çawomir Sta≈Ñczak
Technische Universit√§t Berlin
Abstract

Building upon previous work on the relation between secrecy and channel resolvability, we revisit a secrecy proof for the multiple-access channel (MAC) from the perspective of resolvability. In particular, we refine and extend the proof to obtain novel results on the second-order achievable rates. Then we characterize the resolvability region of the memoryless MAC by establishing a conceptually simple converse proof for resolvability that relies on the uniform continuity of Shannon‚Äôs entropy with respect to the variational distance. We discuss the operational meaning of the information theoretic concept of semantic security from the viewpoint of Ahlswede‚Äôs General Theory of Information Transfer and show interesting implications on the resilience against a large class of attacks even if no assumption can be made about the distributions of the transmitted messages. Finally we provide details on how the resolvability results can be used to construct a wiretap code that achieves semantic security.

‚Ä†‚Ä†footnotetext: The work was supported by the German Research Foundation (DFG) under grant STA864/7-1 and by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research under grant 16KIS0605. This paper was presented in part at the 4th Workshop on Physical-Layer Methods for Wireless Security held during the 2017 IEEE Conference on Communications and Network Security¬†[21].

I Introduction

With an increasing number of users and things being connected to each other, not only the overall amount of communication increases, but also the amount of private and personal information being transferred. This information needs to be protected against various attacks. In fact, for some emerging applications such as e-health services where sensitive medical data might be transmitted using a Body Area Network, the problem of providing secrecy guarantees is a key issue.

As discovered by Csisz√°r¬†[12] and later more explicitly by Bloch and Laneman¬†[10] and investigated by Yassaee and Aref [45] for the multiple-access case, the concept of channel resolvability can be applied to provide such guarantees; in essence, an effective channel is created by an encoder in such a way that the output observed by a wiretapper is almost independent of the transmitted messages, which renders the output useless for the wiretapper. Moreover, the concept can also be used in point-to-point settings as a means of exploiting channel noise to convey randomness in such a way that the distribution observed at the receiver can be accurately controlled by the transmitter.

In this paper, we explore channel resolvability in a multiple-access setting in which there is no communication between the transmitters, yet they can control the distribution observed at the receiver in a non-cooperative manner. More precisely, given a multiple-access channel with an ideal or desired output distribution under some input distribution (see Figure ¬†1), the resolvability problem for this multiple-access channel consists in finding for each transmitter a finite sequence of codewords (called a codebook) such that if each transmitter chooses a codeword at random and independently of the other transmitter, then the MAC output well approximates the given ideal output distribution. The coding setting is illustrated in Figure¬†2 where each codeword is a tuple of nùëõn elements of the input alphabet and nùëõn is referred to as the block length.

The first part of the paper deals with the resolvability problem for the memoryless MAC, while in the second part we show how the concept of channel resolvability can be exploited to achieve strong operational secrecy guarantees over a wiretap MAC.

I-A Literature

To the best of our knowledge, the concept of approximating a desired output distribution over a communication channel using as little randomness as possible at the transmitter was first introduced by Wyner¬†[43], who used normalized Kullback-Leibler divergence as a similarity measure between the actual and the desired output distribution. Han and Verd√∫¬†[25] introduced the term channel resolvability for a similar concept; however, instead of the Kullback-Leibler divergence, they used the variational distance as a metric and showed, among others, the existence of a codebook that achieves an arbitrarily small variational distance by studying the expected variational distance of a random codebook.

A stronger result stating that the probability of drawing an unsuitable random codebook is doubly exponentially small is due to Cuff¬†[14]. Related results were proposed before by Csisz√°r¬†[12] and by Devetak¬†[16] for the quantum setting, who based his work on the non-commutative Chernoff bound¬†[3]. Further secrecy results that are either based on or related to the concept of channel resolvability can be found in Hayashi¬†[27], Bloch and Laneman [10], Hou and Kramer¬†[29], and Wiese and Boche¬†[42], who applied Devetak‚Äôs approach to a multiple-access setting. Cuff¬†[14] presented a result on the second-order rate; a related result was proposed by Watanabe and Hayashi¬†[41]. Resolvability for MACs has been explored by Steinberg¬†[38] and later by Oohama¬†[36]. Explicit low-complexity codebooks for the special case of symmetric MACs have been proposed by Chou, Bloch and Kliewer¬†[11].

Converse results for channel resolvability have been proposed by Han and Verd√∫¬†[25] and, for the multiple-access channel, by Steinberg¬†[38]. However, since these studies consider channels with memory and allow for arbitrary input and output distributions (in particular, they need not be identical or independent across channel uses), these results are not directly transferrable to the memoryless case considered in this paper. Converse proofs for the memoryless single-user case were given by Wyner¬†[43] and later by Hou¬†[30]; however, instead of the variational distance considered in this study, they assumed the Kullback-Leibler divergence as a similarity measure so that the results of [30] cannot be applied directly either.

Security concepts from cryptography have been redefined as secrecy concepts for the information theoretic setting by Bellare, Tessano and Vardy in [7] and [6], where the authors also discussed the interrelations between these concepts; however, the proposed schemes involve some cryptographic elements, such as shared secrets between transmitter and legitimate receiver or shared (public) randomness. To the best of our knowledge, there are currently no results explicitly linking the concept of semantic security to the operational meaning in communication theory.

Wiretap codes that achieve semantic security over the Gaussian channel have been proposed by Ling, Luzzi, Belfiore and Stehl√©¬†[33]. Thangaraj¬†[39] showed how to construct semantically secure wiretap codes for the single-user channel and already noted the link to channel resolvability. Goldfeld, Cuff and Permuter¬†[23][22] showed how channel resolvability techniques can be used to obtain wiretap codebooks that achieve semantic security over the single-user channel; the technique had been previously sketched by Cuff¬†[15].

Liang and Poor¬†[32], Ekrem and Ulukus¬†[18], as well as Liu and Kang¬†[34] provided converse results for related multiple-access wiretap channels, but these results do not carry over in a straightforward fashion to the converse results for the channel model we consider in this paper to study achievable secrecy rates.

II Overview and Main Contributions

The main contributions of this study can be summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We characterize the resolvability region of the discrete memoryless multiple-access channel. Section IV proves the direct theorem and a result on the second-order rate, while Section V deals with the converse theorem.

  2. 2.

    In Section VI we show how resolvability can be exploited to achieve strong secrecy and semantic security, and discuss operational implications of semantic security.

In the remainder of this section, we discuss our results in more detail and explain their implications in the context of secrecy and security. We start with a basic definition and refer the reader to Section III for further definitions.

In particular, the statement shows that not only does a sequence of codebook pairs achieving the rates exist, but if they are constructed randomly, the probability of drawing a bad pair of codebooks vanishes doubly exponentially with increasing block length. Precisely, we show the following.

Then there exist Œ≥1,Œ≥2>0subscriptùõæ1subscriptùõæ20\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}>0 such that for sufficiently large block length nùëõn, the codebook distributions of block length nùëõn and rates R1subscriptùëÖ1R_{1} and R2subscriptùëÖ2R_{2} satisfy

To prove this theorem, we revisit the proof in¬†[42], thereby focusing on channel resolvability. We use a slightly different technique than that in¬†[14], which we extend to the multiple-access case to provide an explicit statement and a more intuitive proof for a result only implicitly contained in¬†[42]. In an excursus, we show how a slight refinement of the same technique similarly as in¬†[14] yields also a partial second-order result.

In Section¬†VI, we discuss different notions of secrecy and the interconnection between them. In particular, in addition to the classical concept of strong secrecy, we review the notions of distinguishing security and semantic security, both of which originate from the field of cryptography. Distinguishing security allows us to decompose the problem for wiretap coding into a problem of coding for the MAC and a channel resolvability problem as shown in Figure¬†4. The concept of semantic security, on the other hand, which is implied by distinguishing security, has some very strong operational implications, some of which we explore from the point of view of Ahlswede‚Äôs General Theory of Information Transfer¬†[1].

‚à•p‚àíq‚à•TV:=12‚àëa‚ààùíú|p(a)‚àíq(a)|=‚àëa‚ààùíú[p(a)‚àíq(a)]+.\lVert p-q\rVert_{\mathrm{TV}}:=\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left\lvert p(a)-q(a)\right\rvert=\sum\limits_{a\in\mathcal{A}}\left[p(a)-q(a)\right]^{+}.

Given random variables Aùê¥A, BùêµB and Cùê∂C distributed according to rA,B,Csubscriptùëüùê¥ùêµùê∂r_{A,B,C}, we define the (conditional) information density as

i‚Äã(a;b):=log‚Å°rB|A‚Äã(b|a)rB‚Äã(b),i‚Äã(a;b|c):=log‚Å°rB|A,C‚Äã(b|a,c)rB|C‚Äã(b|c).formulae-sequenceassignùëñùëéùëèsubscriptùëüconditionalùêµùê¥conditionalùëèùëésubscriptùëüùêµùëèassignùëñùëéconditionalùëèùëêsubscriptùëüconditionalùêµùê¥ùê∂conditionalùëèùëéùëêsubscriptùëüconditionalùêµùê∂conditionalùëèùëêi({a};{b}):=\log\frac{r_{B|A}(b|a)}{r_{B}(b)},~{}~{}i({a};{b}|{c}):=\log\frac{r_{B|A,C}(b|a,c)}{r_{B|C}(b|c)}.

The (conditional) mutual information is the expected value of the (conditional) information density. We use H‚Äã(A)ùêªùê¥H(A) and H‚Äã(A|B)ùêªconditionalùê¥ùêµH(A|B) to denote Shannon‚Äôs (conditional) entropy.

The following inequality was introduced in¬†[8] and¬†[20]; we use a refinement here which follows e.g. from¬†[5].

IV Proof of the Direct Theorem

In this section, we prove Theorem¬†2. Together with the observation that the resolvability region ùíÆùí≤,qZsubscriptùíÆùí≤subscriptùëûùëç\mathcal{S}_{\mathcal{W},q_{Z}} is convex, by a standard time sharing argument, this yields the direct part of Theorem¬†1 as an immediate consequence.

First, we show a slightly weaker version of Theorem¬†2.

The denominator of the fraction is almost surely not equal to 00 as long as the numerator is not equal to 00. We implicitly let the summation range only over the support of the denominator, as we do in all further summations.

IV-A Second Order Rates

Although the probability statement in Theorem¬†2 is quite strong in the sense that it guarantees a doubly exponentially low probability of drawing a bad pair of codebooks, a weak spot of the theorem as stated is that the constants Œ≥1subscriptùõæ1\gamma_{1} and Œ≥2subscriptùõæ2\gamma_{2} are guaranteed to be positive, but can be arbitrarily small depending on the channel, the input distribution and the codebook rates and that the theorem is only valid for sufficiently large nùëõn. So in particular, if we are given a fixed nùëõn (even a very large one), we cannot draw any conclusions for the error probabilities of codebooks of block length nùëõn. However, a closer examination of the proof shows that stronger statements are possible in this case. In this subsection, we give details how the proof of Theorem¬†2 can be modified so that it yields the following second-order result.

Theorem 7.

Suppose the rates R1,R2subscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2R_{1},R_{2} depend on nùëõn in the following way:

The question of how the achievable second-order rates behave near the line connecting these two corner points should be a subject of further research.

‚Ñôùíû1,ùíû2‚Äã(Patyp,1>Œº1‚Äã(1+1n))‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àí2‚ÄãŒº12n‚Äãexp‚Å°(n‚Äãmin‚Å°(R1,R2))).subscript‚Ñôsubscriptùíû1subscriptùíû2subscriptùëÉatyp1subscriptùúá111ùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùúá12ùëõùëõsubscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2}}\left(P_{\mathrm{atyp},1}>\mu_{1}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\right)\right)\\ \leq\exp\left(-\frac{2\mu_{1}^{2}}{n}\exp(n\min(R_{1},R_{2}))\right). (25)

Reasoning along similar lines shows

‚ÑôYn,Zn‚Äã((Yn,Zn)‚àâùíØ2,Œµ2n)‚â§Œº2subscript‚ÑôsuperscriptùëåùëõsuperscriptùëçùëõsuperscriptùëåùëõsuperscriptùëçùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùíØ2subscriptùúÄ2ùëõsubscriptùúá2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{Y^{n},Z^{n}}((Y^{n},Z^{n})\notin\mathcal{T}_{2,\varepsilon_{2}}^{n})\leq\mu_{2}

so that a further application of Lemma¬†4 yields

‚Ñôùíû1,ùíû2‚Äã(Patyp,2>Œº2‚Äã(1+1n))‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àí2‚ÄãŒº22n‚Äãexp‚Å°(n‚Äãmin‚Å°(R1,R2))).subscript‚Ñôsubscriptùíû1subscriptùíû2subscriptùëÉatyp2subscriptùúá211ùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùúá22ùëõùëõsubscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2}}\left(P_{\mathrm{atyp},2}>\mu_{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\right)\right)\\ \leq\exp\left(-\frac{2\mu_{2}^{2}}{n}\exp(n\min(R_{1},R_{2}))\right). For the typical term, we use the definitions¬†(20) and¬†(21) with the typical set ùíØ1,Œµ1nsuperscriptsubscriptùíØ1subscriptùúÄ1ùëõ\mathcal{T}_{1,\varepsilon_{1}}^{n}, and observe that for any fixed ynsuperscriptùë¶ùëõy^{n} and znsuperscriptùëßùëõz^{n}, we can apply Lemma¬†3 with A=Xùê¥ùëãA=X, B=YùêµùëåB=Y, C=Zùê∂ùëçC=Z and Œ¥=1/nùõø1ùëõ\delta=1/\sqrt{n} to obtain

Now proceeding in a similar manner as in¬†(78) to¬†(81) shows

‚Ñôùíû1,ùíû2‚Äã(Ptyp‚Äã(zn)>1+3n|ùíû1‚àà‚ÑÇzn)‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àí13‚Äãn‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àín‚Äã(I‚Äã(Y;Z)+Œµ2‚àíR2))),subscript‚Ñôsubscriptùíû1subscriptùíû2subscriptùëÉtypsuperscriptùëßùëõ1conditional3ùëõsubscriptùíû1subscript‚ÑÇsuperscriptùëßùëõ13ùëõùëõùêºùëåùëçsubscriptùúÄ2subscriptùëÖ2\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2}}\left(P_{\mathrm{typ}}({z^{n}})>1+\frac{3}{\sqrt{n}}~{}|~{}\mathcal{C}_{1}\in\mathbb{C}_{z^{n}}\right)\\ \leq\exp\left(-\frac{1}{3n}\exp(-n(I(Y;Z)+\varepsilon_{2}-R_{2}))\right),

The theorem then follows from (85) to (88) in the appendix. ‚àé

Next, we bound

as shown in (The MAC Resolvability Region, Semantic Security and Its Operational Implications) through (93) in the appendix.

Taking into consideration that

and that (n+1)/n‚â§2ùëõ1ùëõ2(n+1)/n\leq 2, this proves¬†(33).

Furthermore, we note that

VI Channel Resolvability and Secrecy

In this section, we summarize some existing notions of secrecy and a few facts about their relations to each other, and also discuss their operational meaning. We then show explicitly how our channel resolvability results can be applied to derive a secrecy result for the multiple-access wiretap channel that not only implies strong secrecy, but has even stronger operational properties than the classical notion of strong secrecy. We start by providing additional definitions in Subsection¬†VI-A, then we discuss different notions of secrecy and interconnections between them in Subsection¬†VI-B. Then we show how our resolvability results can be used to achieve secrecy over the multiple-access channel. To this end, we first repeat a well-known result on achievable rates for the multiple-access channel in Subsection¬†VI-C which is the second crucial ingredient besides resolvability for the secrecy theorem we prove in Subsection¬†VI-D.

VI-A Additional Definitions

In contrast to the other sections, in this section we will also look at probability distributions on the alphabet of possible messages. We therefore use ‚Ñ≥1:={1,‚Ä¶,exp‚Å°(n‚ÄãR1)}assignsubscript‚Ñ≥11‚Ä¶ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1\mathcal{M}_{1}:=\{1,\dots,\exp(nR_{1})\} and ‚Ñ≥2:={1,‚Ä¶,exp‚Å°(n‚ÄãR2)}assignsubscript‚Ñ≥21‚Ä¶ùëõsubscriptùëÖ2\mathcal{M}_{2}:=\{1,\dots,\exp(nR_{2})\} to denote the message alphabets; for convenience we denote by ‚Ñ≥:=‚Ñ≥1√ó‚Ñ≥2assign‚Ñ≥subscript‚Ñ≥1subscript‚Ñ≥2\mathcal{M}:=\mathcal{M}_{1}\times\mathcal{M}_{2} the message alphabet of both transmitters. VI-B Secrecy Concepts and their Operational Meanings

In this subsection, we give a short overview over some notions of information-theoretic secrecy. We adapt the notation in the sources we are citing in such a way that it conforms with the notation we have been using in this paper, which is specific to the multiple-access wiretap channel, but the concepts apply also to (and have originally been introduced for) wiretap channels with only one transmitter.

Before we give formal definitions of secrecy, we first take a look at what operational implications we want a good notion of secrecy to have. In¬†[1], Ahlswede generalized the communication task in the following way: The transmitter picks a message M‚àà‚Ñ≥ùëÄ‚Ñ≥M\in\mathcal{M}, encodes it and transmits the codeword over a channel. The receiver then aims not necessarily at decoding the exact message MùëÄM, but rather has a partition {‚Ñ≥1,‚Ä¶,‚Ñ≥‚Ñì}subscript‚Ñ≥1‚Ä¶subscript‚Ñ≥‚Ñì\{\mathcal{M}_{1},\dots,\mathcal{M}_{\ell}\} of ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M}, i.e. disjoint subsets of ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M} with ‚à™k=1‚Ñì‚Ñ≥k=‚Ñ≥superscriptsubscriptùëò1‚Ñìsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëò‚Ñ≥\cup_{k=1}^{\ell}\mathcal{M}_{k}=\mathcal{M}. Its task is then to reconstruct kùëòk such that M‚àà‚Ñ≥kùëÄsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëòM\in\mathcal{M}_{k}. The transmitter does not know the exact partition Œ†Œ†{\Pi} that defines the receiver‚Äôs task, but has only a subset {Œ†1,‚Ä¶,Œ†t}subscriptŒ†1‚Ä¶subscriptŒ†ùë°\{{\Pi}_{1},\dots,{\Pi}_{t}\} of the set of all possible partitions of ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M} and has to encode the message in such a way that the receiver can decode with high probability no matter which partition in this set defines its task, or put differently, we assume there is one receiver for each partition and we want each receiver to be able to decode with high probability. Ahlswede gave a list of specializations of this very general concept that he deemed potentially useful for real-world communication systems. Two of these are:

  1. 1.

    t=1ùë°1t=1 and the only partition Œ†1subscriptŒ†1{\Pi}_{1} is the partition of singletons {{m}:m‚àà‚Ñ≥}conditional-setùëöùëö‚Ñ≥\{\{m\}:m\in\mathcal{M}\}. Here the receiver‚Äôs task amounts to Shannon‚Äôs classical decoding problem.

  2. 2.

    t=|‚Ñ≥|ùë°‚Ñ≥t=\lvert\mathcal{M}\rvert and the set of partitions is

    {{{m},‚Ñ≥‚àñ{m}}:m‚àà‚Ñ≥}.conditional-setùëö‚Ñ≥ùëöùëö‚Ñ≥\Big{\{}\big{\{}\{m\},\mathcal{M}\setminus\{m\}\big{\}}:m\in\mathcal{M}\Big{\}}.

    This corresponds to the problem of identification codes introduced by Ahlswede and Dueck¬†[2].

These decoding tasks can not only be understood as having to be performed by a legitimate receiver in cooperation with the transmitter, but can also be seen as possible attacks carried out by a wiretapper, where each possible attack is defined by a partition on ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M}. For instance, we could deem the wiretapper‚Äôs attack to have been successful only if it is able to decode the exact message which corresponds to item 1), or, by an alternative definition, we might choose a particular message mùëöm that the wiretapper has to identify corresponding to one of the partitions of item 2) and thus obtain a much weaker definition of what constitutes a successful attack.

The best thing we might wish for in this context would be that the wiretapper be unable to perform attacks corresponding to any possible partition of the message set. In fact, demanding this is equivalent to insisting that the wiretapper shall not be able to decode any function of the transmitted message (because a function induces a partition of its domain via the preimages of singletons in its range).

Shannon introduced the concept of information theoretic secrecy and required for his condition of perfect secrecy¬†[37] that I‚Äã(M;Ztapn)=0ùêºùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõ0I(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n})=0. In Shannon‚Äôs cipher system, both legitimate receiver and wiretapper get the same channel output, but transmitter and legitimate receiver share a key, which is unknown to the wiretapper.

Later, Wyner introduced the wiretap channel, where the wiretapper‚Äôs channel output is degraded with respect to the legitimate receiver‚Äôs channel output, but wiretapper and legitimate receiver do not share a key. In order to be more amenable to analysis, he weakened Shannon‚Äôs perfect secrecy criterion and introduced the concept of weak secrecy¬†[44]. A sequence of codes for increasing block length nùëõn is said to achieve weak secrecy if I‚Äã(M;Ztapn)/nùêºùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõùëõI(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n})/n approaches 00 as nùëõn tends to infinity, where MùëÄM is assumed to be uniformly distributed over the message set. It turns out that a sequence of codes can achieve weak secrecy while the total amount of information leaked still tends to infinity with the block length approaching infinity. Therefore, the notion of¬†strong secrecy was introduced by Maurer¬†[35] which demands that I‚Äã(M;Ztapn)ùêºùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõI(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}) shall approach 00 as nùëõn tends to infinity, where MùëÄM is still assumed to be distributed uniformly.

Strong secrecy has been shown to imply that full decoding is only possible with an error probability that approaches the probability of guessing correctly without any channel output at all and it has also been shown to provide some resilience against identification attacks¬†[9], however, some messages might remain identifiable and no method was proposed of ensuring that any particular given message mùëöm not be identifiable.

This leads us to the concept of semantic security, which originates from the field of cryptography¬†[24], but has also been redefined to yield an information-theoretic secrecy criterion¬†[7][6].

Following the discussion in¬†[6] and adapting to our notation, we say that a sequence of codebooks achieves semantic security if

maxŒ†,‚ÑôM(maxf:ùíµtapn‚ÜíŒ†‚ÑôM,Ztapn(M‚ààf(Ztapn))‚àímaxg‚ààŒ†‚ÑôM(M‚ààg))subscriptŒ†subscript‚ÑôùëÄsubscript:ùëì‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptùíµtapùëõŒ†subscript‚ÑôùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõùëÄùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõsubscriptùëîŒ†subscript‚ÑôùëÄùëÄùëî\max\limits_{{\Pi},\mathbb{P}_{M}}\bigg{(}\max\limits_{{f}:\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}\rightarrow{\Pi}}\mathbb{P}_{M,Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}}(M\in{f}(Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}))\\ -\max\limits_{{g}\in{\Pi}}\mathbb{P}_{M}(M\in{g})\bigg{)} (46)

tends to 00 with n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\rightarrow\infty, where Œ†Œ†{\Pi} ranges over all partitions of ‚Ñ≥‚Ñ≥\mathcal{M} and ‚ÑôMsubscript‚ÑôùëÄ\mathbb{P}_{M} over all possible probability distributions of M‚àà‚Ñ≥ùëÄ‚Ñ≥M\in\mathcal{M}. The positive term can be seen as the probability that the wiretapper solves its decoding task successfully given its channel output and an optimal decoder, while the second term can be seen as subtracting the probability that the decoding task is solved without knowledge of the wiretapper‚Äôs channel output (i.e. by optimal guessing). This notion has a wide range of operational implications in the sense that it is impossible for the wiretapper to carry out an attack corresponding to any of Ahlswede‚Äôs general communication tasks, as we show in Examples¬†1 and¬†2.

Remark 4.

(46) remains unchanged even if we allow stochastic wiretapper‚Äôs decoders, i.e. if we let fùëì{f} range over functions that map from ùíµtapnsuperscriptsubscriptùíµtapùëõ\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n} to probability mass functions on Œ†Œ†{\Pi}.

On the other hand, it is not easy to prove directly that a particular wiretap code achieves semantic security. We therefore define a notion of secrecy that is more amenable to analysis, namely, we say that a sequence of wiretap codebooks achieves distinguishing security if

maxm1,m2,m~1,m~2‚à•pZtapn|ùíû1‚Äã(m1,‚ãÖ),ùíû2‚Äã(m2,‚ãÖ)‚àípZtapn|ùíû1‚Äã(m~1,‚ãÖ),ùíû2‚Äã(m~2,‚ãÖ)‚à•TV\max\limits_{m_{1},m_{2},\tilde{m}_{1},\tilde{m}_{2}}\lVert p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(m_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(m_{2},\cdot)}\\ -p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(\tilde{m}_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(\tilde{m}_{2},\cdot)}\rVert_{\mathrm{TV}} (47)

approaches 00 with nùëõn tending to infinity.

maxm1,m2‚à•pZtapn|ùíû1‚Äã(m1,‚ãÖ),ùíû2‚Äã(m2,‚ãÖ)‚àíp‚à•TV\displaystyle\max\limits_{m_{1},m_{2}}\lVert p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(m_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(m_{2},\cdot)}-p\rVert_{\mathrm{TV}}

approaching 00, where pùëùp is an arbitrary probability mass function on ùíµtapnsuperscriptsubscriptùíµtapùëõ\mathcal{Z}_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n} that does not change with m1subscriptùëö1m_{1} or m2subscriptùëö2m_{2}.

In [6], these and several other related concepts of information-theoretical secrecy and their interrelations are discussed. It turns out that distinguishing and semantic security are equivalent and strictly stronger than strong secrecy. On the other hand, if the definition of strong secrecy is strengthened to demand that maxpM‚Å°I‚Äã(M;Ztapn)subscriptsubscriptùëùùëÄùêºùëÄsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõ\max_{p_{M}}I(M;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}) approaches 00, where pMsubscriptùëùùëÄp_{M} ranges over all distributions of MùëÄM (not just uniform), then it becomes equivalent to the notions of distinguishing and semantic security. We will present here versions of the proofs adapted to our notation only for the implications that seem most important to us in this context, namely that distinguishing security, which we show in Theorem¬†10 can be achieved over the multiple-access channel, implies both strong secrecy (Lemma¬†6) and semantic security (Lemma¬†7).

We now give two examples to show how the concept of semantic security implies resilience to the Ahlswede attacks discussed before. Example¬†1 is a special case of Example¬†2, but we lay it out explicitly anyway because we believe that it illustrates the ideas involved in a particularly accessible way and that the type of attack it describes could be particularly relevant in practice.

which shows that as (46) tends to 00, the wiretapper‚Äôs minimum error probabilities approach values that can be achieved by stochastic guessing without observing any channel output at all.

Example 2 (General Ahlswede Attacks).

As a second, slightly more involved example, we show the operational meaning of semantic security for attacks defined by more general partitions. Lemma 7.

(46) is upper bounded by (47). In particular, distinguishing security implies semantic security.

VI-C Coding for the Multiple-Access Channel

The capacity region of the multiple-access channel is well known and proofs can be found in almost any textbook on information theory, however, usually only the existence of a suitable codebook is proven. We need here the slightly stronger statement that the probability of randomly choosing a bad codebook is exponentially small, which requires only a slight modification of these proofs, which is, however, normally not given in the textbooks explicitly. For the sake of completeness, we state here the result that we need and present a proof that is similar to the one given in¬†[26].

Theorem 9.

Suppose ùí≤=(ùí≥,ùí¥,ùíµ,qZ|X,Y)ùí≤ùí≥ùí¥ùíµsubscriptùëûconditionalùëçùëãùëå\mathcal{W}=(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{Y},\mathcal{Z},q_{Z|X,Y}) is a channel, qXsubscriptùëûùëãq_{X} and qYsubscriptùëûùëåq_{Y} are input distributions, R1<I‚Äã(X;Z|Y)subscriptùëÖ1ùêºùëãconditionalùëçùëåR_{1}<I(X;Z|Y), R2<I‚Äã(Y;Z|X)subscriptùëÖ2ùêºùëåconditionalùëçùëãR_{2}<I(Y;Z|X) and R1+R2<I‚Äã(X,Y;Z)subscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2ùêºùëãùëåùëçR_{1}+R_{2}<I(X,Y;Z). Then there exist decoding functions

dn:ùíµn‚Üí{1,‚Ä¶,exp‚Å°(n‚ÄãR1)}√ó{1,‚Ä¶,exp‚Å°(n‚ÄãR2)}:subscriptùëëùëõ‚Üísuperscriptùíµùëõ1‚Ä¶ùëõsubscriptùëÖ11‚Ä¶ùëõsubscriptùëÖ2d_{n}:\mathcal{Z}^{n}\rightarrow\{1,\dots,\exp(nR_{1})\}\times\{1,\dots,\exp(nR_{2})\}

and Œ≥1,Œ≥2>0subscriptùõæ1subscriptùõæ20\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}>0 such that for large enough block length nùëõn, the codebook distributions of block length nùëõn and rates R1subscriptùëÖ1R_{1} and R2subscriptùëÖ2R_{2} satisfy

‚Ñôùíû1,ùíû2‚Äã(‚Ñ∞>exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥1‚Äãn))‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥2‚Äãn),subscript‚Ñôsubscriptùíû1subscriptùíû2‚Ñ∞subscriptùõæ1ùëõsubscriptùõæ2ùëõ\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2}}\left(\mathcal{E}>\exp(-\gamma_{1}n)\right)\leq\exp\left(-\gamma_{2}n\right), (56)

where we define the average decoding error probability as

‚Ñ∞:=‚àëm1=1exp‚Å°n‚ÄãR1‚àëm2=1exp‚Å°n‚ÄãR2assign‚Ñ∞superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëö11ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëö21ùëõsubscriptùëÖ2\displaystyle\mathcal{E}:=\sum\limits_{m_{1}=1}^{\exp{nR_{1}}}\sum\limits_{m_{2}=1}^{\exp{nR_{2}}} exp‚Å°(‚àín‚Äã(R1+R2))ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2\displaystyle\exp(-n(R_{1}+R_{2}))
‚ÑôZn(dn(Zn)‚â†(m1,m2)|Xn=C1(m1),Yn=C2(m2)).\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_{Z^{n}}\Big{(}&d_{n}(Z^{n})\neq(m_{1},m_{2})~{}\big{|}~{}\\ &X^{n}=C_{1}(m_{1}),Y^{n}=C_{2}(m_{2})\Big{)}.\end{aligned}
Proof.

VI-D Achievable Secrecy Rates under Distinguishing Security

Theorem 10.

Suppose ùí≤=(ùí≤legit,ùí≤tap)ùí≤subscriptùí≤legitsubscriptùí≤tap\mathcal{W}=({\mathcal{W}_{\mathrm{legit}}},{\mathcal{W}_{\mathrm{tap}}}) is a wiretap channel, VùëâV is a random variable, qX|Vsubscriptùëûconditionalùëãùëâq_{X|V} and qY|Vsubscriptùëûconditionalùëåùëâq_{Y|V} are input distributions and R1subscriptùëÖ1R_{1} and R2subscriptùëÖ2R_{2} are rates satisfying

I‚Äã(X;Ztap|V)ùêºùëãconditionalsubscriptùëçtapùëâ\displaystyle I(X;Z_{\mathrm{tap}}|V) <I‚Äã(X;Zlegit|Y,V)‚àíR1absentùêºùëãconditionalsubscriptùëçlegitùëåùëâsubscriptùëÖ1\displaystyle<I(X;Z_{\mathrm{legit}}|Y,V)-R_{1} (73)

Then there exist randomness rates L1,L2subscriptùêø1subscriptùêø2{L_{1}},{L_{2}}, decoding functions

and Œ≥1,Œ≥2>0subscriptùõæ1subscriptùõæ20\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}>0, such that for sufficiently large nùëõn, the probability ‚Ñôbadsubscript‚Ñôbad\mathbb{P}_{\mathrm{bad}} under the wiretap codebook distribution of drawing a bad pair of codebooks is less than exp‚Å°(‚àín‚ÄãŒ≥2)ùëõsubscriptùõæ2\exp(-n\gamma_{2}). A pair of codebooks is considered to be bad if it does not satisfy all of the following:

  1. 1.

    (Distinguishing Security). For any m1,m2subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2m_{1},m_{2}, we have

    ‚à•pZtapn|ùíû1‚Äã(m1,‚ãÖ),ùíû2‚Äã(m2,‚ãÖ)‚àíqZn‚à•TV‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥1‚Äãn),subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëùconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptùëçtapùëõsubscriptùíû1subscriptùëö1‚ãÖsubscriptùíû2subscriptùëö2‚ãÖsubscriptùëûsuperscriptùëçùëõTVsubscriptùõæ1ùëõ\lVert p_{Z_{\mathrm{tap}}^{n}|\mathcal{C}_{1}(m_{1},\cdot),\mathcal{C}_{2}(m_{2},\cdot)}-q_{Z^{n}}\rVert_{\mathrm{TV}}\leq\exp(-\gamma_{1}n),

    i.e. the wiretap codebooks achieve distinguishing security and the variational distance vanishes exponentially.

  2. 2.

    (Average decoding error). We have ‚Ñ∞‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àín‚ÄãŒ≥1)‚Ñ∞ùëõsubscriptùõæ1\mathcal{E}\leq\exp(-n\gamma_{1}), where

    ‚Ñ∞:=assign‚Ñ∞absent\displaystyle\mathcal{E}:= ‚àëm1=1exp‚Å°n‚ÄãR1‚àëm2=1exp‚Å°n‚ÄãR2‚àë‚Ñì1=1exp‚Å°n‚ÄãL1‚àë‚Ñì2=1exp‚Å°n‚ÄãL2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëö11ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëö21ùëõsubscriptùëÖ2superscriptsubscriptsubscript‚Ñì11ùëõsubscriptùêø1superscriptsubscriptsubscript‚Ñì21ùëõsubscriptùêø2\displaystyle\sum\limits_{m_{1}=1}^{\exp{nR_{1}}}\sum\limits_{m_{2}=1}^{\exp{nR_{2}}}\sum\limits_{\ell_{1}=1}^{\exp{n{L_{1}}}}\sum\limits_{\ell_{2}=1}^{\exp{n{L_{2}}}}
    exp‚Å°(‚àín‚Äã(R1+R2+L1+L2))ùëõsubscriptùëÖ1subscriptùëÖ2subscriptùêø1subscriptùêø2\displaystyle\exp(-n(R_{1}+R_{2}+{L_{1}}+{L_{2}}))
    ‚ÑôZn(dn(Zn)‚â†(m1,‚Ñì1,m2,‚Ñì2)|Xn=C1(m1,‚Ñì1),Yn=C2(m2,‚Ñì2)).\displaystyle\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_{Z^{n}}\Big{(}&d_{n}(Z^{n})\neq(m_{1},\ell_{1},m_{2},\ell_{2})~{}\big{|}~{}\\ &X^{n}=C_{1}(m_{1},\ell_{1}),Y^{n}=C_{2}(m_{2},\ell_{2})\Big{)}.\end{aligned}

    is the average decoding error; i.e. the legitimate receiver is able to (on average) reconstruct both the messages and the randomness used at the transmitters with exponentially vanishing error probability.
